docs.lead_paragraph: Every Monday morning, patients infected with the AIDS virus come to the red-brick clinic in this impoverished community of dilapidated shacks. In the waiting room, babies wail, nurses hustle and some young women fidget on wooden benches as their earrings dangle and their chipped pink toenails gleam. The clinic looks like one of the hundreds of medical centers overwhelmed by South Africa's AIDS epidemic. Yet there is little talk of depression or dying here.

headline.main: Free AIDS Drugs in Africa Offer Dose of Life

docs.abstract: Number of private initiatives providing free or low-cost AIDS drugs has slowly but steadily grown in South Africa, offering rare rays of hope in country with highest number of people infected with HIV; vast majority of AIDS patients in South Africa die because they cannot afford drugs common in West; most people treated with drugs show dramatic improvements, gaining weight and strength to fight off killer diseases; Doctors Without Borders runs largest free program; number of people getting AIDS drugs through their insurers has doubled in last two years as drug prices have begun to fall; map; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Rumsfeld Warns He Will Ask Congress for More Billions'' (news article, Feb. 6): Here we are with a federal deficit of more than $200 billion, 33 million people living in poverty (at least 11 million of them children), 41 million people without health insurance and an unemployment rate that is almost 6 percent, but Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld finds that the $380 billion proposed military budget (by far the world's largest) simply won't do.
docs.abstract: Sally Saul letter on Feb 6 articles scores Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld's bid for even larger military budget and Pentagon's bid for exemption from environmental rules

docs.lead_paragraph: After nearly a week of rallies, rancor and crowded emergency rooms, organizers of the work slowdown by New Jersey doctors have called for an end to their five-day job action. Citing what they said were encouraging talks with legislators about reining in rising malpractice insurance rates, the organizers have recommended that doctors across the state resume normal business hours Monday morning.

headline.main: Organizers Call for an End To Doctors' Work Slowdown

docs.abstract: Organizers of work slowdown among New Jersey doctors decide to end weeklong efforts aimed at putting limits on rising malpractice insurance rates, and resume normal business hours; cite encouraging talks with New Jersey legislators as reason for decision; Joseph F Vitale, co-chairman of Senate Committee for Health, Human Services and Senior Citizens, is also encouraged by end of slowdown (M)
